places.name: Cambridge
places.description: Cambridge is the county town of Cambridgeshire.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: Miller and William Watson

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesBonnet
persons.description: Genevan lawyer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: StephenHales
persons.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

persons.name: Jean-Nicolasde la Hire
persons.description: French doctor and botanist who developed a technique for botanical illustration which has never been fully explained. He was the son of mathemetician and astronomer Philippe de la Hire.

persons.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
persons.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: ErasmusDarwin
persons.description: Physician and natural philosopher who was member of the Lunar Society and friend of Priestley and Watt; also a correspondent with Beddoes. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnHunter
persons.description: Leading Scottish surgeon and anatomist who worked in London, holding several major positions. Brother of William Hunter. FRSL.

persons.name: Thomas AndrewKnight
persons.description: Knight was a botanist and horticulturalist. He was the second president of the Royal Horticulture Society. Davy frequently fished on Knight's esates in the Welsh Marches. FRSL.

persons.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
persons.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: StephenHales
persons.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

persons.name: JanIngenhousz
persons.description: Dutch-born British physiologist, biologist and chemist. He was one of the discoverers of the process of photosynthesis. FRSL.

persons.name: JeanSenebier
persons.description: Genevan naturalist; pioneer in field of photosynthesis.

persons.name: JanIngenhousz
persons.description: Dutch-born British physiologist, biologist and chemist. He was one of the discoverers of the process of photosynthesis. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnPringle
persons.description: Physician who served as President of the Royal Society of London, 1772-1778. Created a baronet. FRSL.

works.name: A Discourse on the Different Kinds of Air, Delivered at the Anniversary Meeting of the Royal Society
works.author: John Pringle

persons.name: Thomas CharlesHope
persons.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: ErasmusDarwin
persons.description: Physician and natural philosopher who was member of the Lunar Society and friend of Priestley and Watt; also a correspondent with Beddoes. FRSL.

places.name: Siberia
places.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: JohnJay
persons.description: American statesman, patriot, diplomat, abolitionist, signatory of the Treaty of Paris, and a Founding Father of the United States. Davy quotes him as the author of a letter on a species of apple with one sweet and one sour side.

works.name: Communications to the Board of Agriculture; on subjects relative to the husbandry, and internal improvement of the country.
works.author: John Jay

persons.name: Henry VIII
persons.description: King of England from 22 April 1509 until his death in 1547.
